entry.title: Combined summary - ossification and misaligned incentive concerns
entry.summary:
The email also addresses the narrative surrounding the role of miners in providing network security. The author argues that miners only provide double spend insurance and do not offer security for the rest of the network. They emphasize the importance of private keys and note that miners have no control over them. The author suggests abandoning this narrative and focusing on other aspects of Bitcoin's development.
Another concern raised in the email is the issue of taxation. The author believes that a direct tax is less acceptable to people than a hidden tax. They argue that high direct taxes are more irritating, while hidden taxes, such as inflation, can go unnoticed. The author states that in any alternative financial system, it is unlikely that the situation would be different. They draw an analogy between transaction tax being equivalent to on-chain fees and inflation tax being equivalent to the block reward. The author asserts that miners can only collect payment for providing network security up to the amount collected through these taxes.
The email then presents a thought experiment regarding maintaining a constant level of difficulty and adjusting the block reward accordingly. The author suggests that the level of network security is limited by the availability of resources and the acceptance of global energy consumption. They argue that there is a natural level of network security that corresponds to a certain level of inflation. The author cites a comment from the internet that compares this concept to central banks setting interest rates but with algorithmic control tied to security.
Furthermore, the email mentions growing awareness of the lack of a free market between active and passive participants in Bitcoin. It suggests that this issue will become a problem in the future. The email acknowledges the increasing acceptance of proposals to address this situation and highlights the importance of the free market over the finite supply of Bitcoin.
In summary, the email discusses concerns about the influence of service providers on Bitcoin's development, questions the narrative surrounding miners' role in network security, raises concerns about taxation, explores the relationship between network security and inflation, and mentions the lack of a free market in Bitcoin. These issues highlight the potential conflicts between service providers' interests and the needs of regular users, as well as the importance of maintaining a balance between security, decentralization, and scalability in the Bitcoin ecosystem.
